19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

We were close but lots were out of groceries in 1904 when Lumsden Valley was flooded and Saskatoon bridge was washed out. So we could get nothing until the ferry was built to carry things across. They had one freight train to bring the supplies and the people from Saskatoon to Lumsden. And they fired with the engine with wood.

19. Have you ever refused to eat something out of groceria locally produced? Give details.

The area close but not open out of flooded in 1904 when Yuma River Valley was washed out. We could get nothing until the river was back to carry things across. They had no freight train to bring the supplies and the people from Clarkston to Yuma. And they found the Chagrin on the road.

We came back and we went to the Harley Hotel Hall and then we came back and stayed at the Humane Club and there we had a big party with the Town Council. We had a lot of fun and we danced all night long and we had a great time.

As can be seen from the above, the early settlers faced many challenges in obtaining food and supplies. They had to be resourceful and creative to survive in the harsh conditions of the wilderness.

had to get up and chase the coyotes away. We couldn't sleep for they made so much noise and they tried to get our chickens. We had them still in the crates where we brought them up since we had no other place to put them. In 1904 we had a big prairie fire so we had too back fire so it wouldn't come to our buildings. We fought fire all day. We were so stiff next morning that we could hardly move our eyes, eyebrows and the hair on our arms.
